fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every chain complex injects into its cone, whose cohomology is zero. So cohomology is effaceable. Dually every chain complex is a quotient of its cocone, hence homology is coeffaceable. Therefore by we finish the proof.

Homology H_\bullet as a functor from the category of chain complexes (bounded from below) of {\mathcal{A}} to {\mathcal{A}} is a homological universal \delta-functor. Dually, cohomology is a cohomological universal \delta-functor.

Every chain complex injects into its cone, whose cohomology is zero. So cohomology is effaceable. Dually every chain complex is a quotient of its cocone, hence homology is coeffaceable. Therefore by we finish the proof.

Given a cohomological \delta-functor T^\bullet, if each T^n for n > 0 is effaceable, then it is a universal \delta-functor. Dually, if a homological \delta-functor is coeffaceable, then it is universal.

Given an object X, consider the exact sequence given by effaceability 0 \longrightarrow X \longrightarrow I \longrightarrow Y \longrightarrow 0. Then we have a long exact sequence 0 \to T^0 X \to T^0 I \to T^0 Y \xrightarrow{\delta} T^1 X \xrightarrow{0} T^1 I. and the rest breaks into infinitely many short exact sequences 0 \to T^{n+1} I \to T^{n+1} Y \to T^{n+2} X \to 0.

For independence, we first prove that if two effacements X \to I, X \to I' are connected by a morphism I \to I', then the resulting transformations are equal. This is essentially the same as the proof of naturality, except \varphi is replaced with {\textrm{id}}. Now any two effacements are connected by a zigzag, since we can take the diagonal X \to I \times I' and project out.

An additive functor F : {\mathcal{A}} \to {\mathcal{B}} is effaceable iff for each object X in {\mathcal{A}}, there exists a monomorphism X \to I whose image under F is zero. Dually, it is coeffaceable iff for each object X there exists an epimorphism P \to X whose image under F is zero.
